Bio:
b.1947 - d.2020

Radcliffe 1969; HLS '72. 

U.S. District Court Judge for the Southern District of New York 1994-2012; senior status 2012-2020.

AUSA 1979-1984. Associate or Adjunct Prof Fordham Law 1984-2020 (1st Black faculty member). First openly LGBT African-American judge. 

Key cases: Central Park Five civil case; she rejected NYC's motion to dismiss a lawsuit by the 5 defendants; NYC settled w/them for $41M. Terrorism: Sentenced a Bin Ladin advisor to life in prison after he admitted stabbing a prison guard. Oversaw civil suit against Christine Todd Whitman, head of EPA accused of misleading public about risk of toxic air pollution after 9/11; found CTW had made statements so misleading, they were “conscience-shocking"; but app ct dismissed suit in 2008. At time of Batts' death, she was slated to preside over embezzlement trial of Michael Avenatti, accused of swindling $300,000 from client Stormy Daniels.
Why Notable?: Associate or Adjunct Prof Fordham Law 1984-2020 (1st Black faculty member). First openly LGBT African-American judge. Key cases: Central Park Five civil case; she rejected NYC's motion to dismiss a lawsuit by the 5 defendants; NYC settled w/them for $41M.

Bio: b.1941 - d.2009 Chairman and chief executive of Beneficial Corp. (consumer finance company) from 1976 to 1998 when it was bought by Household International, then ran Knickerbocker Management, a private financial management firm. Pioneer in the field of second mortgages and home equity loans. Philanthropist to Harvard and other schools, rowing, equestrian sports. Major Republican donor. Tax evasion investigations included an IRS audit for 2005-2008 focusing on his offshore accounts. In 2013, IRS exonerated FC posthumously w/no penalties or fines. Town Commissioner in Jupiter Island, FL.     Suicide by gunshot in 2009. HLS connections: Member, Dean's Advisory Board. Caspersen Student Center & HLSL's Caspersen Room named after him. Controversy over the naming arose when news of the IRS audit was made public. Endowed 2 HLS professorships: Beneficial and Finn MW Caspersen and Household International. 2003 Chair of HLS's capital campaign, and pledged $30M, the largest single donation in HLS history. All 4 of his sons graduated HLS; their admission was criticized in a book by journalist and H alum Daniel Golden criticizing the role of privilege and wealth in elite college admissions.
Why Notable?: Philanthropist to Harvard and other schools, rowing, equestrian sports. Major Republican donor. Town Commissioner in Jupiter Island, FL.  HLS connections: Member, Dean's Advisory Board. Caspersen Student Center & HLSL's Caspersen Room named after him. Controversy over the naming arose when news of the IRS audit was made public. Endowed 2 HLS professorships: Beneficial and Finn MW Caspersen and Household International. 2003 Chair of HLS's capital campaign, and pledged $30M, the largest single donation in HLS history.

Bio: In 1990, Barack Obama was elected as the first Black president of the Harvard Law Review. Obama, who graduated from HLS in 1991, would later represent Illinois in the U.S Senate, and in 2008 would become the 44th President of the United States, and the first African-American president.
HLS Alum and first African-American First Lady
first Black woman to serve in Congress from the state of Alabama
1990, first woman president of Ireland
First Vietnamese American to be appointed a judge in the United States in 1992.

The documentary tells the story of Margaret Montoya, the first Latina to be admitted to Harvard Law School. The documentary celebrates her admissions, sustained leadership, and consistent commitment to civil rights, racial justice and health equity.

b. 1988.   First deaf-blind graduate of Harvard Law School, 2013.   Disability rights activist advocating for accessible digital services.   2013-16: Member of Disability Rights Advocates, Berkeley, CA.   2016-present: Full-time non-litigation disability rights activist, speaker, consultant.   2019: Author of memoir, "Haben: The Deafblind Woman Who Conquered Harvard Law".   Select speeches: TED talk; White House commemoration of ADA's 25th anniversary with Obama/Biden

Bio: A 1928 HLS graduate, Redding became the first African American lawyer in Delaware in 1929. He was a champion of civil rights in Delaware and nationally, serving as part of the NAACP legal team that challenged school segretation in Brown v. Board of Education

Bio: 1994 HLS graduate, Douglas Hallward-Driemeir argued before the Supreme Court in Obergefell v. Hodges, the landmark case which secured marriage equality across the United States.  Driemeir argued that marriages valid in one state must be recognized as valid by other states.

Former Director General of the Chinese Maritime Customs Service, he played a central role in returning customs authority from foreign domination to Chinese control, as well as regaining China's tariff autonomy.  In his name, Chang's daughter Julia (张之香, MA 1967, first U.S. aMBA@ssador of Asian descent) and Son-in-law Stuart Bloch (@LL.B.@ 1967) founded F.Y. China foundation in 1988. The foundation has has helped more than 60 Chinese earn Harvard Law degrees, and today those scholars are among China's most influential judges, attorneys, professors and legal experts. https://uscet.org/fy-chang-foundation)  and https://blogs.harvard.edu/guorui/2008/11/19/rule-of-law-commitment-and-the-future-of-china-and-us-fy-chang-foundations-twenty-year-celebration/

Bio: The first non-white judge on the High Court of South Africa, Navi Pillay served as the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights from 2008-2014. As a judge on the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, she set the legal precedent that rape and sexual assault could be considered an act of genocide.
